history.content:
If you just want to do traditional analog design, then taking EE130 for device physics should be sufficient at the beginning. Of course, exposure to quantum mechanics and statistical mechanics in general is useful for understanding devices and the origin of noise. For high speed electronics, electromagnetic courses such as EE117 and physics 110AB might be more helpful initially.

There are other related subfields in EE that requires more knowledge about physics, such as physical electronics (devices, photonics, etc.) and recently the field of quantum hardware is also getting more attention. In general, taking a quantum mechanics class is always inspiring. Given that you are also majored in math, physics 137A should actually be quite easy to grasp since it’s basically applied linear algebra with some canonical differential equations. Physics 141A is quite specialized and theoretical, so I recommend EE230BC instead if you want to learn more about solid state electronics. Also physics 112 is more fundamental than 141A in my opinion since it also provides insight to circuit noise and information theory which is widely applicable in communication. 

BTW, make sure you have taken EE120 before taking any other EE upper divs. It is the fundamental and best class in EE:)

children.subject:
120 is related to all the fields mentioned below.
On analog circuit side, 105 -> 140 -> 142 (+126, 117) -> 240B, 242B. 142 is the class that combines knowledge of LC circuits, transmission lines, noise, Fourier analysis, device parameters, etc. (There are also digital circuit classes, but they are not tightly related to physics courses.)
On the device physics side, 130 -> 230B/C. The 130/230 series rely heavily on solid-state physics.
MEMS: 147 -> 247B
Photonics and other physical electronics: EE117 or 118, Physics 137A/B -> EE232, 236 + AMO physics classes
Of course, there are also quantum-algorithm-related courses on the CS side.

What other courses would you recommend to in electrical engineering that can relate the physics courses mentioned other than ee 130 and ee 117? I am an engineering physics major currently planning to take ee 120 and would like to know a general pathway to upper div eecs courses to potentially take.

It's better if you have taken physics 7B or know some basic thermodynamics (from maybe high school chemistry). Luckily, physics upper div generally build knowledge from a more fundamental approach, so in my opinion, they're actually easier to grasp than lower divs which usually hide the details. In terms of mathematical content, 112 is the course that challenges your understanding of multivariate calculus and probability theory. It'll also be very helpful and inspiring if you have some background in optimization theory so that you can realize the duality between thermodynamic variables. You don't really need to master the math I mentioned above, but usually, the more math background you have, the more you'll get from a physics class.

<md>I can second the point about 137A being like a linear algebra class for physics majors... Is anyone able to comment on whether physics 112 is also approachable for people with math background but no lower-division physics?</md>

history.content:
Hello.

I am an L&S intended cs major that is also majoring in applied math. I was considering taking a cluster in applied math that possibly includes physics 137ab and 141. As for my cs major, I am mainly looking at more ee focused courses right now (105, 140, 151). 

I was wondering if these physics classes are worth taking if I am interested in this aspect of ee, or if it is just better of to take other ee courses insted.

Thank you.
history.subject: Relevance of solid state/quantum physics to analog engineering
